Address: 312 S Main St, Ann Arbor, MI 48104

summary.snippet: "Was especially fond of the crispy rice, Korean fried chicken, and sushi rolls."
"The food , the atmosphere , the service was all top notch."
"Absolutely recommend ordering apps/main dishes rather than sushi here."

most_relevant.description: Great sushi experience in downtown Ann Arbor. Everything was fresh, flavorful, and well prepared. The small plates were delicious and I enjoyed the cauliflower, crispy rice, and tuna dishes. Try the Azalea role, as well. The vibe is very modern and moody with dim lighting and elegant touches down to the plating and cutlery. The place is a bit hidden and hard to find – look for the glass door next to Blue Llama and head down the stairs.

This is the best restaurant in Ann Arbor, hands down. The food was so unique and absolutely delicious. Reminds me of stuff you would find in New York, especially with how they plate it. Cool and relaxed decor that’s definitely perfect for a date night or if you wanna slip in for one of their unique drinks. Do yourself a favor and get something off the small plates portion of the menu. There is not a single miss here! I will definitely be back here again and I couldn’t recommend this place any harder.

Everything was great at our recent visit to Azalea! The service was amazing and made sure we were always good with our drinks and food. The food was all delicious! We especially liked the Dolsot with short rib, Gochujang Rigatoni, and the Wagyu Dumplings!
very good food. Absolutely recommend ordering apps/main dishes rather than sushi here. The crispy rice is the best menu item followed by the summer salad, tempura. Wagyu dumplings are okay.

They don’t have big sign outside but inside was full of great foods and chic interior. Great for small and intimate party. I love all menus but especially kimchi seafood paella and beef stew. Roll was delicious.
We had the opportunity to eat at Azalea over the weekend. The food was great. And the service was amazing. We will definitely going back to try the rest of the menu.

We started off with their house cocktails, I ordered the Spring Azalea which was yumyum, I could have drank 4-5 of them. The Midori Mojito was also very nice, not too sweet. We ordered the verde cauliflower dish which was colorful and the sauce was delicious. The fried chicken was seasoned well, juicy, a bit on the oily side and it came with the spicy chilli oil sauce and we got to test the garlic soy sauce which we both preferred. The best and most unique dish was their winter salad which had a great variety of veggies and citrus and an amazing dressing which had fresh squeezed OJ, mustard (i think), savory and sweet complimenting the subtle bitter winter veg. I thought it was on par with a Spencer salad. The atmosphere seems in transition, like between a nightclub and restaurant with some kitschy aspects like the fake flowers outside and bedazzled buddha. On my way to the bathroom there were old arcade games in the hallways and random stuff. It is not an upscale dining experience but the drinks and food are very enjoyable and the staff are friendly and casual. We'll be back to try more drinks and food.

The food is really bad and really expansive.
The shrimp in my soba is flavorless, they didn't season it at all. The shrimp is of good quality though.
They don't even have proper takeout boxes.
